ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: See question 1 above and question 7 below.Good, but not as an intro to linguistics. It's definitely better with a linguistics background.

The course is a solid introduction to historical linguistics, covering traditional methodologies such as the comparative method as well as newer approaches such as computational phylogenetics. We learned how language reconstruction may contribute to knowledge about linguistic theory as well as prehistorical cultures and population movements. While this is primarily a linguistics course, it does address interfaces with anthropology, archaeology, history, and evolutionary biology. The course is designed for students with widely varying backgrounds in linguistics. I would recommend this course if you are interested in the topic.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: A better grasp of language in general.
I will most likely use comparative methods in my dissertation research, so having an introduction to historical methods is essential.
